oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glimpses of Nashville, Tennessee: Scene on Cumberland River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the steamer “Henry Harley” docked at the loading area along the Cumberland River, in downtown Nashville, Tennessee. This steamboat was a low water boat in the Louisville-Evansville trade. Steamboats, in their heyday, provided the fastest, most convenient, and most economical method of transportation available. The "Henry Harley" sank in 1906 at Buffalo Landing, between Granville and Carthage, after hitting a big rock while backing in during landing. Forms part of Glimpses of Nashville. 1 booklet
